Award.AwardTitle: CAREER:Fast refreshing holographic 3D display using highly sensitive photorefractive polymer

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this proposal is to develop a fast, refreshing holographic 3D display in reflection geometry using highly sensitive photorefractive (PR) polymers. Currently available refreshable PR 3D display uses transmission geometry with refreshing time slower than that required for many display applications. The PI proposes a transformative approach that uses carrier multiplying sensitizers to develop fast refreshing reflection holograms. Efficient charge transfer and excellent miscibility with other PR components will be achieved by suitably functionalizing the sensitizer. Transient four-wave mixing measurements will be used to determine the PR properties of the samples.

Intellectual Merits: The proposed work will provide new insights into carrier generation, multiplication and separation when inorganic and graphene quantum dot sensitizers are used in PR polymer. The proposed approach of carrier multiplication is appropriate for PR polymers since an external electric field capable of rapidly separating the charges is typically required for its operation. In addition, holographic 3D display in reflection geometry developed using this highly optimized sample will provide fast refreshing time, many perspectives of the image and wide viewing angles.
Broader Impact: A holographic reflection 3D display will be very attractive for several applications including entertainment, product development and urban planning. Furthermore, enhancement of carrier generation and separation using the proposed sensitizers will have a significant impact on improving the quantum efficiency in many other optoelectronic and photovoltaic devices as well. In addition, the theoretical and experimental insight gained from the subject area will be integrated into a polymer photonics course.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project's objective was to develop light-sensitive materials to make composites for holographic and optoelectronic device applications. These materials are called sensitizers and are used to provide/enhance the light sensitivity of optoelectronic devices. A few high-performing materials were developed as a part of this project.

The photorefractive polymer films are used to record holograms optically. This project resulted in the development of graphene particle-doped photorefractive samples. Two-dimensional graphene crystallites were synthesized by a chemical exfoliation method from highly oriented pyrolytic graphite. The graphene crystallites were mixed with a conducting polymer and other components to make a photorefractive polymer composite. This composite is made into a photorefractive device by sandwiching between two transparent conducting glass electrodes. The holographic recording efficiency was evaluated using the four-wave mixing technique. It has been found that graphene crystallites enhanced the dynamic holographic performance of the composite compared to commonly used sensitizers. It has also been observed that graphene crystallites generate interesting nonlinear optical properties.

The project also enabled the development of a method to make new superstructures as sensitizers. The superstructures were developed by growing light-sensitive perovskite quantum dots (PQDs) directly on a platform like graphenes or carbon nanotubes. Since PQDs are known for their high light sensitivity, the efficacy of these particles as sensitizers was studied by measuring properties like responsivity and detectivity in a phototransistor geometry. An extremely thin (less than 50nm) superstructure showed excellent responsivity and specific detectivity. This demonstrates that the PQD superstructures are beneficial for the development of highly efficient ultrathin optoelectronic devices. Moreover, it has been found that the superstructures show a light-assisted memory effect. Due to its light-assisted memory effect, a device called optoelectronic synapse was developed to demonstrate its potential application in brain-inspired neuromorphic devices. Facial recognition was demonstrated using these devices with the assistance of machine learning as a signature of Its effectiveness in neuromorphic computing. 

This funding has resulted in 19 journal publications and the filing of five provisional/full patents. More papers are in preparation. The project also partially or fully supported five graduate students and five undergraduate students.
